properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert - Telephone Service Disruption Alert Updated
properties.Summary:
Description: There is an incident that has affected telephone and cell phone communications in the area surrounding the Hamlet of Sangudo. Communication services are being restored by TELUS and are expected to be complete in all areas in the next 24 to 48 hour period. ### Severe damages have occurred to the telephone and cell phone communication system in the area of the Hamlet of Sangudo, and a large service area surrounding the Hamlet. As of Monday, April 1, approximately 35 customers remain without land line services. It is estimated that within the next 24 hour period, land line services will be restored for these customers. Cell and Internet services have been restored. TELUS will continue to make more robust repairs over the next several weeks as required.
Expires: 2019-04-08T12:38:17-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Lac Ste. Anne County, 2019-04-01T12:36:25-06:00, NAADS-CA-AB-AEA1-5670
Area: Lac Ste. Anne County
properties.Author: Lac Ste. Anne County

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard is likely Tuesday night and into Wednesday. A low pressure system now over Labrador will move into the Davis Strait Tuesday. Strong northwest winds will develop late Tuesday giving blizzard conditions Tuesday night and into Wednesday. Gusts of 90 km/h are possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-02T08:37:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T14:18:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0758367071.2019
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard Tuesday night and into Wednesday. A low pressure system now over Labrador will move into the Davis Strait Tuesday. Strong northwest winds will develop late Tuesday giving deteriorating visibilities in blowing snow Tuesday afternoon. Sustained blizzard conditions are expected Tuesday night and Wednesday morning. Gusts of 90 km/h are possible. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-02T11:22:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T19:23:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2891884071.2019
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR QUESNEL The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority issued an Air Quality Advisory for Quesnel on March 29, 2019. The Air Quality Advisory remains in effect due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter that are expected to persist until weather conditions change. Exposure to dust is particularly a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, coughing or wheezing, follow the advice of your health care provider. Real-time air quality information from Quesnel and other B.C. communities can be found at: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-04-01T23:40:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-04-01T15:41:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0406571293.2019
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR SMITHERS The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory for Smithers because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### Children, including teenagers, are at higher risk from outdoor air pollution because they often spend time being active outdoors. Young people are more likely to have asthma and their lungs are still developing. For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-04-01T23:52:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-04-01T15:53:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2731815924.2019
Area: Bulkley Valley and The Lakes - northwest including Smithers
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong westerly winds gusting up to 100 km/h are forecast along parts of the coast overnight tonight and Tuesday. Winds are expected to gradually ease Tuesday evening. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-02T10:30:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T18:31:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0310462374.2019
Area: Northern Peninsula East
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Strong southeasterly winds with gusts up to 100 km/h will develop near noon and weaken as they become southwesterly later this afternoon. ### Very strong winds may push your vehicle around especially on roads through mountain passes and along deep valleys. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-01T22:59:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T13:23:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0656717693.2019
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Marine Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Westerly gales of 35 to 45 knots are affecting the St. Lawrence marine estuary. These winds are ushering colder air and will cause waves of 3 to 4 meters and freezing spray. Marine conditions will be particularly hazardous for the small crafts in this early fishing season. Conditions will improve gradually on Tuesday. ###
Expires: 2019-04-02T11:53:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T19:54:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3723870063.2019
Area: Pointe à Michel to Pointe-des-Monts, Pointe-des-Monts to Anticosti - northern half, Pointe-des-Monts to Anticosti - southern half
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snow will persist until Tuesday Morning. Strong winds will continue to combine with the fresh snow to produce reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Additionally, these winds will continue to strengthen with gusts reaching 100 km/h overnight and Tuesday morning before they begin to subside. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 35 cm are forecast by Tuesday morning before the snow tapers off. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-02T10:52:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T18:53:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1264507159.2019
Area: Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong northwest winds are giving blizzard conditions for Paulatuk today. These winds will weaken late this evening ending the blizzard overnight. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-02T06:53:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T14:54:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2961612500.2019
Area: Paulatuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall likely for Wednesday. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras Tuesday evening and then move northeastward towards the Maritimes overnight Tuesday night and Wednesday. Rain associated with the low will likely spread across Prince Edward Island later Wednesday morning and will fall heavy at times during the day and persist until ending Wednesday night. Parts of Prince county could see the rain mix with or change to snow for a time later in the day. Total rainfall amounts in excess of 25 millimetres are possible across most of the Island. These amounts combined with the heavy rates of rainfall could lead to ponding and risk of localized flooding, especially given the ground remains at least partially frozen in some areas of the province. The rain will be accompanied by strong and gusty southeasterly winds, shifting to strong northwesterly winds Wednesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-02T02:53:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T18:54:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1296947563.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Temperatures have fallen to just below zero resulting in a period freezing rain this evening. Freezing rain will transition to snow later this evening. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-02T03:54:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T18:55:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3747170169.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rainfall likely for Wednesday. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras Tuesday evening and then move northeastward towards the Maritimes overnight Tuesday night and Wednesday. Rain associated with the low will likely spread across Nova Scotia Wednesday morning and will fall heavy at times during the day and persist until ending from west to east Wednesday night. Total rainfall amounts of 25 to 50 millimetres are generally expected across the province but could locally reach 75 mm in some areas. These amounts combined with the heavy rates of rainfall could lead to ponding and risk of localized flooding, especially given the ground remains at least partially frozen in some areas of the province. The rain will be accompanied by strong and gusty southeasterly winds, shifting to strong northwesterly winds Wednesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-02T02:53:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T18:54:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1011370130.2019
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, freezing rain and significant rainfall likely for Wednesday afternoon and Wednesday night. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras Tuesday evening and then move northeastward towards the Maritimes overnight Tuesday night and Wednesday. Snow mixed with rain or freezing rain will likely spread across the Islands Wednesday afternoon then change to rain at times heavy Wednesday evening before ending after midnight. Total rainfall amounts in excess of 25 millimetres are possible. These amounts combined with the heavy rates of rainfall could lead to ponding and risk of localized flooding. The rain will be accompanied by strong and gusty southeasterly winds, shifting to strong northwesterly winds on Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-02T02:52:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T18:53:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0854153642.2019
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant early spring storm will bring rain and snow to much of New Brunswick on Wednesday. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras Tuesday evening and then move northeastward towards the Maritimes overnight Tuesday night and Wednesday. Snow or rain is likely to begin Wednesday morning over southwestern New Brunswick and then spread quickly across the province by noon. At this time, southern New Brunswick will likely see significant amounts of rain, likely in excess of 25 mm. Central, eastern and northeastern New Brunswick will likely see snow or snow mixed with rain, with amounts in excess of 10 cm or more in some areas. Northwestern New Brunswick will likely only receive light amounts of precipitation from this system. There is considerable uncertainty in the exact location of the rain/snow boundary, as a slight shift in track or intensity of this system could significantly affect both the amounts and type of precipitation received. Precipitation will end Wednesday evening as the low tracks by to the southeast of the province. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-02T02:52:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-01T18:53:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2233719407.2019
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, Grand Lake and Queens County, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, Saint John and County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Grand Manan and Coastal Charlotte County, Woodstock and Carleton County, Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Kent County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Kouchibouguac National Park, Fundy National Park, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway, Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula
